metadata.feature_description: Configure how domain names are handled in usernames

steps.action: Navigate to Settings > Extensions > Authentication Systems > DNNPro_ActiveDirectoryAuthentication > Site Settings
steps.expected: AD Authentication settings page should be displayed with Default Domain field visible
steps.actual: AD Authentication settings page displayed correctly with Default Domain field visible

steps.action: Scroll to view the Default Domain field
steps.expected: Default Domain field should be visible and empty by default
steps.actual: Default Domain field is visible and empty (default state)

steps.action: Enter 'TESTDOMAIN' in the Default Domain field
steps.expected: Value should be entered in the field
steps.actual: TESTDOMAIN value entered successfully in the Default Domain field

steps.expected: Settings should be saved and value should persist
steps.actual: Settings saved successfully and TESTDOMAIN value persisted after page reload

test_scenarios.scenario_name: Verify Strip Domain Name setting is not exposed in UI

steps.action: Review all settings visible in the AD Authentication Site Settings page
steps.expected: Verify whether Strip Domain Name checkbox is visible or hidden
steps.actual: Strip Domain Name checkbox is NOT visible in the UI. Code review confirmed the control has Visible='false' attribute set in Settings.ascx (line 35-36)

test_scenarios.scenario_name: Test Login Page Without AD Authentication Enabled

steps.action: Log out and navigate to the login page with AD Authentication disabled
steps.expected: Login page should show only standard DNN login form (no Windows Authentication tab)
steps.actual: Login page displays standard DNN login form with Username/Password fields only - no Windows Authentication tab visible when AD Authentication is disabled

observations: The 'Strip Domain Name' feature exists in the code (Configuration.cs and Settings.ascx.cs) but is intentionally hidden from the UI with Visible='false' attribute in Settings.ascx lines 35-36. This setting cannot be tested via UI.
The Default Domain field is functional and allows configuration of a default domain prefix for users logging in without specifying a domain.
Testing actual AD login with DOMAIN\username or username@domain.com formats requires a real Active Directory environment which is not available in this test setup.
When AD Authentication is disabled (Enabled checkbox unchecked), the Windows Authentication tab does not appear on the login page as expected.
